title: Two Down, the Astros Retain Their Confidence
text:
HOUSTON — For about seven decades, it was a foolproof way to lose the World Series: Drop the first two games at home, and you’re finished. The first nine times a team did that — from the 1914 Philadelphia Athletics to the 1972 Cincinnati Reds — it never recovered.

That is where the Houston Astros found themselves late Wednesday night, after a tight Game 2 devolved into a 12-3 thrashing by the Washington Nationals at Minute Maid Park. The teams head to Nationals Park for Game 3 on Friday, and the Astros will pack their swagger.

“Not a lot of teams win 107 games a year,” shortstop Carlos Correa said. “This is a special team; this is not just a random team. If there’s a team out there that can do it, it’s us.”

The Astros may be further emboldened by the fate of three of the last four teams to fall into this trap. The 1985 Kansas City Royals, the 1986 Mets and the 1996 Yankees all lost the first two games at home but ended up winning the title. The 1999 Atlanta Braves did not, and the situation has not arisen since. The urgency is obvious.
